snippet: Residents of Raqqa are angry at the U.S. because food and fuel prices have soared, power blackouts have prevailed and order is now threatened by a power vacuum.
abstract: American airstrikes on Syrian city of Raqqa, self-proclaimed capital of Islamic State, have scattered its fighters and disrupted harsh system they had imposed on residents; gratitude toward United States is limited, however, with food and fuel prices soaring, basic services disappearing and any semblance of stability vanished.

byline.contributor: Ben Hubbard contributed reporting from Baghdad, Karam Shoumali from Sanliurfa, and an employee of The New York Times from Raqqa, Syria.

lead_paragraph: Residents of Raqqa are angry at the U.S. because food and fuel prices have soared, power blackouts have prevailed and order is now threatened by a power vacuum.

headline.main: Strikes by U.S. Blunt ISIS but Anger Civilians
headline.print_headline: Airstrikes Blunt ISIS, but Draw Civilian Ire

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations
